channel.title: A good way to make an autoing "engine"?
channel.description:
Well, I've gotten to load the client through my own class.
Now, im thinking on what kind of autoing "engine" I should make.
First, I thought about just forcing fake events trhough stuff like keyPressed and mouseMoved and stuff.
Then, I thought maybe I could access variables inside the client and do something with that.
Anyone got some ideas? All help will be appreciated.
*BTW This is wit the current RSClient.*

item.title: A good way to make an autoing "engine"?
item.dc:creator: @Nerice Nerice
item.description:
@Nerice wrote:

[quote=“Krichevskoy, post:9, topic:15418”]I don’t know what people do now, but here are two ideas offhand:

Passive:
Do not touch the client. Write accessor methods for (or reflect) things like NPC/object position. Use this data in your cheating program (located outside the client threads) to control input methods. This constrains you to using only the human game interface and passive client-code interaction. It also requires your program to get the game state every time it wants to do something and requires you to create your own control flow (as opposed to the next one).

Event-based:
Insert hooks at places in the client like object creation / NPC tracking / inventory handling / etc that inform your program of the current game state. This has the benefit of allowing you to make a bot that responds to events rather than follows a script.

No matter what you do, detectability really depends on your implementation (so you could use ideas/snippets from Aryan, just don’t copy the whole thing…)[/quote]

If you use the passive way look into the java.lang.instrument package to help you out…

Read full topic
item.source: A good way to make an autoing "engine"?

item.title: A good way to make an autoing "engine"?
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

well the a number of things you must consider, seperate threads or running in the rs thread, design your solutions around this.

If you can find things in the client let me know that is what i could use. As for input i can provide a full input solution.

Read full topic

item.title: A good way to make an autoing "engine"?
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

I don’t know what people do now, but here are two ideas offhand:

Passive:
Do not touch the client. Write accessor methods for (or reflect) things like NPC/object position. Use this data in your cheating program (located outside the client threads) to control input methods. This constrains you to using only the human game interface and passive client-code interaction. It also requires your program to get the game state every time it wants to do something and requires you to create your own control flow (as opposed to the next one).

Event-based:
Insert hooks at places in the client like object creation / NPC tracking / inventory handling / etc that inform your program of the current game state. This has the benefit of allowing you to make a bot that responds to events rather than follows a script.

No matter what you do, detectability really depends on your implementation (so you could use ideas/snippets from Aryan, just don’t copy the whole thing…)

Read full topic

@Ollie wrote:

Then why were you bugging me for a way in which you could get your client to connect? =P

because i had to hack the jFrame class to make it work before and it was ugly,
so i asked a sexy lady to give me some sexy ideas

item.title: A good way to make an autoing "engine"?
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Taios:

If you dont know much bytecode go check that out first

Chapter 4: http://java.sun.com/docs/books/vmspec/2nd-edition/html/VMSpecTOC.doc.html
Bytecode Ref: http://mrl.nyu.edu/~meyer/jvmref/ref-Java.html

item.title: A good way to make an autoing "engine"?
item.dc:creator: @Taios Taios
item.description:
@Taios wrote:

Ollie:

1337 it takes alot more knowlege to make a bot then to get it to connect, i had a connecting client about ~2Days after the update <3 Krich

Then why were you bugging me for a way in which you could get your client to connect? =P

Aryan is good for referance. =), some what.

I suggest taking a look at a BCEL or another bytecode library. If you dont know much bytecode go check that out first

Read full topic

item.title: A good way to make an autoing "engine"?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“pplsuqbawlz, post:3, topic:15418”]Oh goodness, PLEASE DONT FOLLOW THAT MISERABLE SUGGESTION.

2+2=5 for extremely large values of 2.[/quote]

You definatly wouldn’t want to create a new aryan, but the structure of the random handling and scripts werent bad, it was just the way they did everything else. You can still learn alot from it.
